tasks.task: Loading hay into a storage container.
subtasks: Positioning the hay carrier (likely a trailer or wagon) alongside the hay pile.
Using a pitchfork to transfer hay from the pile into the carrier.
Ensuring even distribution of hay across the carrier to prevent tipping.
Securing the load to prevent shifting during transport.

tasks.task: Operating a combine harvester.
subtasks: Boarding the combine and adjusting settings for optimal crop type (e.g., grain depth, cutter bar height).
Starting the combine’s engines and checking hydraulic systems.
Navigating the combine through the field, steering around obstacles and corners.
Monitoring grain flow and adjusting augers or conveyor belts as needed.
Verifying combine efficiency and making real-time adjustments for maximum yield.

tasks.task: Planting crops using a tractor and planter attachment.
subtasks: Attaching the planters to the front or back of the tractor and setting row spacing according to seed type.
Running the tractor through seed beds, manually or using GPS guidance for precise planting.
Ensuring proper seed depth and coverage with soil, adjusting planter settings as necessary.
Checking soil conditions and seed moisture levels before planting.

tasks.task: Feeding livestock.
subtasks: Preparing feed by mixing hay, grain, and supplements in appropriate proportions.
Transporting the feed to the animal’s enclosure or stall.
Distributing the feed evenly across the enclosure, adjusting amounts based on animal size and needs.
Cleaning feeding areas and watering troughs between feedings to maintain hygiene.

tasks.task: Repairing farm machinery.
subtasks: Identifying the specific issue with the equipment (e.g., engine trouble, hydraulic lines, etc. ).
Tools preparation: gathering necessary tools such as wrenches, screwdrivers, diagnostic equipment.
Disassembling faulty parts to access the problem area.
Replacing or repairing components as needed, e.g., belts, fluids, electrical components.
Reassembling the machinery and performing test runs to ensure proper operation.

tasks.task: Milking cows using a milking machine.
subtasks: Attaching the milking unit to the cow, ensuring incorrect cups are removed and clean ones applied.
Connecting the milking machine to the dairy system (if applicable) and starting the milking process.
Monitoring milk flow and machine operation, adjusting as necessary to prevent injuries or milk quality issues.
Hand washing the cow’s udders as a hygiene step before attachment.
Disconnecting the milking unit and cleaning teats after milking is complete.

tasks.task: Constructing a fence around a new pasture.
subtasks: Measuring the area to determine the required length and posts needed.
Clearing the land of vegetation and debris to prepare for fence installation.
Driving posts into the ground at regular intervals (typically every 6-8 meters).
Stretching wire or mesh between posts and attaching to hardware (gates, corners, etc.).
Securing wires with tensioners and ensuring they are straight and even.

tasks.task: Performing regular livestock checks.
subtasks: Walking through the animal housing or pasture to visually inspect each animal.
Checking for injuries, signs of illness, or unusual behavior that may indicate health issues.
Feeding Sick or weaker animals more frequently or supplementing their diet.
Documenting any issues observed and planning appropriate care actions.
Ensuring all animals are accounted for and noting any that may be missing.

tasks.task: Applying fertilizer to field crops.
subtasks: Mixing dry or liquid fertilizer in a spreader or applying via a broadcast spreader.
Determining the correct application rate based on crop type and soil analysis.
Walking or driving a tractor equipped with the spreader over the field, ensuring even coverage.
Overlapping passes at the edges to prevent gaps.
Cleaning the spreader and disposing of residues properly after use.

tasks.task: Pruning trees or shrubs for orchard maintenance.
subtasks: Identifying branches to remove or prune for structural integrity or light penetration.
Using pruning shears or loppers to cut branches, ensuring clean cuts without damaging the main trunk.
Removing lower branches to allow easier harvesting or improved air circulation.
Clearing debris from the ground around the tree to reduce pest habitat.
Applying a fungicide or sealant to fresh cuts to prevent disease.

tasks.task: Installing solar panels on a barn for renewable energy.
subtasks: Securing permits and obtaining approval from local authorities for the installation.
Measuring the barn roof for size and structural integrity to support solar panels.
Attaching mounting brackets and racking systems to the barn roof, ensuring proper alignment and stability.
Installing solar panels onto the mounting system, connecting them in series.
Wiring the solar array to the existing electrical system or battery storage unit.

tasks.task: Transporting produce to market.
subtasks: Packing the harvested crops into crates, boxes, or refrigerated trucks.
_loading the produce onto a trailer or truck bed, securing with straps or netting.
Driving the vehicle to the market, checking road conditions and adhering to traffic laws.
Unloading at the market and arranging displays for customer purchase.
Engaging with customers, answering questions, and managing payment transactions.

tasks.task: Applying pesticides to crops.
subtasks: Selecting the appropriate pesticide based on crop and pest information.
Mixing the pesticide with water in a sprayer tank according to label instructions.
Attaching the sprayer to the tractor or boom sprayer and conducting a pre-application check.
Driving the sprayer through the field, applying the chemical at the correct pressure and rate.
Deactivating the sprayer and cleaning it thoroughly after use to prevent contamination.

tasks.task: Checking irrigation systems for leaks or blockages.
subtasks: Inspecting the main water line and valves for visible signs of damage or leakage.
Visually checking sprinkler heads or drip irrigation lines for misplaced or clogged components.
Opening control valves section by section to test water flow.
Identifying any problem areas, noting their locations and severity.
Repairing identified issues, which may involve replacing parts, tightening connections, or clearing blockages.

tasks.task: Cutting hay during harvesting.
subtasks: Operating a hay mower to cut grass or legumes to the correct height.
Overlapping mower swaths for complete coverage and efficient drying.
Adjusting the mower's height and capacity based on the field's conditions and the time available.
Monitoring fuel levels and servicing the mower as necessary during extended harvest periods.

tasks.task: Driving a forklift to load containerized goods.
subtasks: Checking the forklift’s lift height and capacity to match the container size.
Positioning the forklift under the product to be moved, ensuring stability.
Engaging the forks, lifting the product, and ensuring it is secure.
Navigating the forklift to the container and aligning the product for placement.
Depositing the load in the container and straightening the forks for the next lift.

tasks.task: Maintaining a tractor’s battery and charging system.
subtasks: Checking the battery's electrolyte levels and tightening connections.
Testing the battery's charge with a voltmeter and replacing if it is below 12.4 volts.
Cleaning terminal posts with a wire brush and applying preventative grease.
Ensuring all electrical connections are secure, especially those leading to the starter motor and lights.

tasks.task: Preparing a plow for use on a tractor.
subtasks: Attaching the plow blades to the front of the tractor using bolts or pins.
Checking the plow's guards and shields for damage and ensuring they are properly secured.
Oil or greasing moving parts of the plow to reduce wear.
Lowering the plow and adjusting depth settings to match soil conditions and cultivation needs.

tasks.task: Conducting a routine barn inspection.
subtasks: Checking the structural integrity of the barn, looking for signs of decay or damage.
Ensuring all doors and windows are secure and weatherproof.
Assessing the ventilation system for adequate airflow and cleanliness.
Checking heating and cooling systems as needed (during different seasons).
Cleaning interior surfaces and removing any accumulation of manure or other waste.

tasks.task: Sowing seeds into prepared fields.
subtasks: Using a seeder attached to a tractor or walking behind, setting the depth and spacing according to the seed type.
Ensuring the seeder is evenly distributing seeds across the field for consistent emergence.
Adjusting seed depth and cover as the weather or soil conditions change.
Walking the fields afterward to check for missed areas and refill as necessary.

tasks.task: Building a retaining wall to prevent soil erosion.
subtasks: Surveying the area for the retaining wall to determine height and length required.
Excavating the foundation trench and compacting the base.
Laying the first course of stones or concrete blocks, ensuring level.
Filling the gaps between blocks with mortar or grout and tamping down.
Construction additional courses, stepping back as needed for proper slope.

tasks.task: Removing a sick animal from the herd.
subtasks: Isolating the animal from the main group to prevent disease spread.
Administering necessary medications or treatment, if available.
Transporting the animal to a veterinarian or to a specialized facility for further care.
Disinfecting the transport area and handling equipment to prevent contamination.
Recording details of the animal's condition and treatment for future reference.

tasks.task: Tilletting a field before planting.
subtasks: Determining the field’s moisture content and adjusting the tiller settings accordingly.
Traversing the field in parallel passes, cutting the soil to the desired depth.
Ensuring uniform tilting by adjusting the angle or height of the tiller’s blades.
Checking for any undisturbed areas and making additional passes if needed.
Leaving the field to dry out if excessively wet to prevent compaction.

tasks.task: Applying lime to correct soil pH.
subtasks: Collecting soil samples from various parts of the field to test pH levels.
Calculating the required amount of lime based on test results and soil analysis.
Distributing the lime evenly over the field, often using a spreader.
Ensuring coverage is uniform and avoiding application in very wet or frozen conditions.
Tilling the lime into the soil to a depth of 6-8 inches to maximize its effect.

tasks.task: Operating a silage harvester to create animal feed.
subtasks: Loading the harvester onto the field, adjusting the cutter head to the appropriate height.
Starting the machine and moving it through the crop, chopping the forage to the desired length.
Overlapping passes at the headlands to ensure all is cut, and driving back towards the unchopped sections.
Chopping the material into uniform sections (typically 2-4 inches long) for optimal fermentation.
Transporting the chopped silage to the storage area in a wagon or directly into a silo.

tasks.task: Conducting regular pasture rotational management.
subtasks: Grasping the current pasture's condition and rotational schedule.
Moving livestock to a new enclosure or paddock that has been rested or fertilized.
Ensuring adequate water and shade in the new area.
Allowing sufficient time for the previous pasture to recover before reusing it.
Monitoring animal behavior and health during the rotation to adjust practices if needed.

tasks.task: Securing a trailer to a vehicle for transport.
subtasks: Aligning the trailer hitch with the vehicle’s coupling point.
Connecting the trailer’s tongue to the vehicle’s hitch using the appropriate coupler.
Towing the trailer slowly to check that the connection is secure and to test brakes.
Securing the trailer with additional tie-downs if necessary for long trips.
Ensuring adequate ventilation and checking for any obstruction that could hinder visibility or movement.

tasks.task: Installing a new water pump for livestock.
subtasks: Determining the water source (well, river, etc.) and selecting an appropriate pump.
Excavating a trench to lay the pipeline from the water source to the animal enclosure.
Installing the water pump at the source and ensuring proper electrical connections or hydraulic power supply.
Connecting the pipeline to the pump and the animal’s water system, ensuring no leaks.
Activating the pump and checking for proper flow rate and distribution across the enclosure.

tasks.task: Manually picking produce from a farm stand.
subtasks: Weeding around each plant to prevent competition and remove debris.
Inspecting the produce for quality (size, color, ripeness) before picking.
Hand-picking fruits or vegetables and placing them into designated boxes or bags.
Preparing the picked items for immediate sale by arranging them attractively in the farm stand.
Pricing the products and ensuring signage is clear for customers to understand pricing and freshness.

tasks.task: Calving assistance for a dairy cow.
subtasks: Recognizing signs of calving distress, such as restlessness or vocalization.
Approaching the cow slowly and gently, providing reassurance.
Using obstetric sleeves or lubricant when examining the cow’s birth canal.
Determining the position and presence of a calf and applying necessary interventions (e.g., adjusting position, delivering the calf).
Providing immediate care for the calf, including removing fluid aspiration and stimulating breathing.

tasks.task: Processing eggs for market.
subtasks: Collecting eggs daily from the henhouse, handling them gently to avoid cracks.
Washing eggs in a solution of warm water and detergent, then rinsing thoroughly.
Inspecting eggs for quality, discarding any that are cracked or misshapen.
Packing eggs into cartons, organizing them by size or batch, and labeling with date.
Storing packed eggs at the proper temperature (40 degrees Fahrenheit or colder) before transportation.

tasks.task: Cutting a hole in the ice on a pond to check for fish health.
subtasks: Locating a safe spot on the ice, considering thickness and snow cover.
Using an auger or chainsaw to create a hole in the ice, ensuring it’s large enough for monitoring.
Observing the water beneath for signs of oxygen levels (bubble patterns, algae).
Checking for the presence of sick or dead fish at the hole.
Monitoring water temperature and adjusting feeding schedules or aeration as needed.

tasks.task: Removing excess hay from the barn to prevent fire hazards.
subtasks: Determining the barn’s capacity for hay storage and scheduling removals accordingly.
Sort the hay for quality and remove any that is moldy, dusty, or of poor condition.
Moving excess hay to a different location, perhaps a storage field, using a tractor and loader.
Stacking the hay in a well-ventilated area away from heat sources and electrical equipment.
Ensuring proper spacing between stored bales or stacks for airflow and ease of access.

tasks.task: Repairing a leaky water pipe.
subtasks: Locating the leak by inspecting for dampness or using soapy water to observe bubbles.
Gently digging around the pipe to expose the leak’s location, taking care not to damage the pipe.
Shutting off the water supply to the pipe or the main source.
Removing the damaged section of pipe and connecting a new section with flare fittings or couplings.
Testing the repaired pipe for leaks by restoring the water supply and observing the joint for any signs of seepage.

tasks.task: Draining a silage pit before applying new silage.
subtasks: Checking for any trapped gases that could pose a safety risk when entering the pit.
Using a mechanical extractor or air mover to ventilate the pit thoroughly.
Removing any remaining silage from the pit using a loader or vacuum system.
Checking the pit walls and floor for damage or settling, noting any repairs needed.
Cleaning the pit thoroughly of debris, residue, and moisture before refilling.

tasks.task: Trimming windmill blades for efficiency.
subtasks: Accessing the windmill blades, usually by climbing the tower or using a lift.
Measuring each blade’s angle to the wind or checking for any damage or warping.
Adjusting the pitch of the blades using a wrench or special tool to optimize airflow.
Balancing the blades for even rotation and reducing torque on the generator.
Testing the adjusted blades’ performance by observing windmill speed and electricity generation.

tasks.task: Hand-harvesting ripe fruit from orchard trees.
subtasks: Selecting fruits that are mature and of good quality, avoiding those that are overly ripe or damaged.
Using a knife or pruning shears to cut fruit from the tree if stems are too tough.
Handling the fruit carefully to avoid bruising, particularly soft-skinned varieties.
Placing harvested fruit into baskets or crates designed for market display.
Storing harvested fruit in a cool, shaded area to maintain freshness until packaging.

tasks.task: Transferring manure into a spreading machine.
subtasks: Gathering the manure from stalls, pens, or stalls, possibly using a shovel or loader.
Pouring the manure into a hopper or container designed for transport.
Ensuring the manure is mixed with bedding (if applicable) to improve aeration and odor control.
Securing the manure in the hopper to prevent spilling during transport to the field.

tasks.task: Applying protective covers to crops at night.
subtasks: Measuring the size of the field to determine the number of protective covers needed (e.g., ground cloths, tunnels).
Setting up the covers over vulnerable crops, ensuring they are taut and secure against wind.
Sealing edges around the cover to trap heat and prevent cold air from damaging the plants.
Removing the covers in the morning when temperatures rise, being cautious not to damage emerging growth.

tasks.task: Controlling weeds in a greenhouse using a锄刀 (chisel).
subtasks: Wearing gloves and protective eyewear when working in the greenhouse.
Inspecting the soil surface for both emerged weeds and weed seedlings.
Using the锄刀 to dig into the soil around each weed, removing the entire root system.
Shallow cultivation to avoid disturbing the young plants’ root systems.
Disposing of the weed debris and checking surrounding areas for new sprouts.

tasks.task: Checking seas relationship to tides for farming purposes.
Building or maintaining saltmarsh infrastructure for tidal filtering.
subtasks: MAINTASK:

tasks.task: Managing bee colonies for pollination.
subtasks: Checking hives for queen health and brood production.
Replacing lost queens or splitting colonies for additional hives.
Feeding bees during extended nectar scarcity periods.
Monitoring for pests (like varroa mites) and diseases, applying treatments as needed.
Preparing equipment for pollination services during crop blossoming periods.

tasks.task: Setting up irrigation lines for a new nursery.
subtasks: Surveying the nursery area to determine the most efficient layout for irrigation lines.
Digging trenches to lay the irrigation pipes, ensuring proper depth to prevent damage.
Connecting the pipes to the main water source and testing for leaks.
Installing emitters at appropriate intervals and angle for uniform water distribution.
Marking the area for future maintenance and adjusting_settings as plant growth necessitates.

tasks.task: Coating fruit trees with fungicide to prevent disease.
subtasks: Selecting an appropriate fungicide based on regional recommendations and tree species.
Mixing the fungicide with water in a sprayer and calibrating the application rate.
Applying the fungicide before bud break or as needed during the growing season to prevent infections.
Following a pattern (crosswise, downwind) to ensure all surfaces are covered.
Disposing of waste material properly and rinsing spraying equipment as per instructions.

tasks.task: Setting up night lighting for livestock protection.
subtasks: Choosing the right type of lighting (safety lights, motion sensors, etc.) for the area.
Wiring the lights to the electrical system, ensuring proper grounding and safety.
Mounting the lights at an appropriate height and angle to cover the area without glare.
Testing the lights to make sure they operate at night and are operational.
Adjusting schedules or lamps as needed to improve coverage or energy efficiency.

tasks.task: Administering worm treatments to poultry.
subtasks: Selecting the appropriate wormer based on flock history and local parasite prevalence.
Mixing the wormer in feed or water, following the label’s instructions on dosage.
Ensuring all birds have access to the medicated feed for the specified duration.
Monitoring birds for any adverse reactions and adjusting the treatment if necessary.
Cleaning waterers and feeders after treatment to prevent contamination.

tasks.task: Installing hay bales in a storage structure.
subtasks: Loading the hay bales onto a hand cart or lift platform if necessary.
Transporting the hay to the storage site, considering safety when using a forklift.
Positioning the hay bales against the walls, allowing for airflow between stacks.
Covering the stored bales with tarps or waterproof covers to prevent moisture damage.
Organizing the hay by type (e.g., grass, alfalfa) and harvest date for easy rotation.

tasks.task: Checking for structural leaks in a dairy barn roof.
subtasks: Inspecting the roof visually for missing shingles, cracks, or sagging sections.
Using a moisture meter to detect hidden water damage inside the building.
Performing a rain test by simulating showers over the roof to identify leak locations.
Recording the locations of detected leaks and planning the necessary repairs.
Sealing or replacing damaged areas to prevent water from entering the building.

tasks.task: Maintaining a farm pond’s water levels.
subtasks: Measuring the water level in the pond using a depth sounder or measure tape.
Reducing water usage during dry periods by adjusting irrigation schedules or finding alternative water sources.
If necessary, pumping water into the pond from a well or nearby reservoir.
Monitoring water quality parameters (pH, temperature, turbidity) and taking corrective actions if levels are off.

tasks.task: Harvesting grass during drought conditions.
subtasks: Assessing the dryness of the grass using the pinch test or fibrometer.
Cutting the grass when it reaches ideal dry matter content for haymaking, which is typically when it breaks easily when gripped between thumb and fingers.
Ensuring the hay is dry enough to prevent mold or heat buildup during baling and storage.
Baling the grass into the appropriate size for storage, considering handling ease and feed quantity.

tasks.task: Conducting a preventative hoof trimming for dairy cows.
subtasks: Examining each cow’s hooves for signs of overgrowth, cracks, or lesions.
Using a hoof trimmer to remove excess horn material, straightening the toe and sides.
Checking balance by repositioning the foot pads as necessary.
Applying hoof dressing to the trimmed areas to promote health and prevent cracking.
Documenting work performed and monitoring for any lameness issues post-trimming.

tasks.task: Propagating plants through cuttings.
subtasks: Selecting stems or branches from a healthy parent plant that are at least one node long.
Cutting the stem at a 45-degree angle just below a node (bud junction).
S strikeouts
Planting the cutting in a sterile rooting medium, such as perlite, vermiculite, or a potting mix.
Maintaining appropriate humidity and temperature levels using a propitiator or plastic cover.
Watering the cutting with a diluted rooting hormone solution if using.

tasks.task: Winterizing a dairy herd.
subtasks: Ensuring all animals are adequately shod and their living quarters are clean and dry.
Adjusting feed rations to higher energy content to maintain body heat.
Providing extra bedding material (e.g., straw) in stalls and maintaining proper ventilation.
Increasing warmth by using heat lamps or electric mats in groups where necessary.
Preparing后备公牛 for breeding in the upcoming breeding season.

tasks.task: Operating a walking plow for small field cultivations.
subtasks: Attaching the plow to a horse-drawn or small four-wheeler-drawn frame.
Adjusting the plow depth and share angle to match the soil’s condition and the crop’s requirements.
Driving the plow through the field while maintaining a straight path to avoid overlaps.
Checking that the plow is moving smoothly without any binding on rocks or stumps.
Observing crop health in the plowed area after several growth cycles to evaluate results.

tasks.task: Driving a tractor with various attachments (e.g., mower, planter, spreader)
subtasks: Starting the tractor and ensuring all gauges and safety features are working properly.
Selecting the appropriate attachment and connecting it securely to the tractor’s hitch.
Adapting the tractor’s speed and turning radius to accommodate the attachment’s size and weight.
Operating the attachment according to manufacturer guidelines (e.g., setting the planter’s depth, adjusting the mower’s height).
Performing regular checks on attachment components for wear or needing adjustments during operation.

tasks.task: Planting winter cover crops.
subtasks: Selecting a cover crop (e.g., rye, clover) appropriate for the local climate and soil.
Ensuring the ground is prepared by tilling or disking to a depth of about 4-6 inches.
Seeds can be applied via broadcast spreading followed by light cultivation.
Overseeding if applicable, covering with a roller or by walking over the area to ensure good seed-soil contact.
Raking the area to smooth the surface and minimize weed competition until germination.

tasks.task: Feeding wild birds for pest control.
subtasks: Choosing the right type of birdseed or suet that attracts birds predatory to farm pests.
Setting up feeders at strategic locations near areas with common pest infestations.
Regularly refilling the feeders and cleaning them to prevent bacterial growth.
Monitoring the effectiveness of the bird control and adjusting strategies if necessary.
Ensuring the feeding program doesn’t inadvertently attract more birds than needed or result in undue competition with livestock.

tasks.task: Applying slurry to fields as fertilizer.
subtasks: Checking the slurry’s pH and nutrient content to ensure it matches the field’s needs.
Transporting the slurry via tanker to the field, dumping it into a spreader or directing it with hoses.
Adjusting the application rate based on the field's size, slope, and water-holding capacity.
Observing the application to prevent excess or runoff, especially on sloped terrain.
Covering any exposed soil areas to minimize erosion and nutrient loss.

tasks.task: Performing daily check-ups on farm machinery.
subtasks: Inspecting tires for air pressure and signs of wear, adjusting as needed.
Checking oil, coolant, and fuel levels in each machine, refilling where necessary.
Confirming all lights, signals, and mirrors are functional for safe operation.
Tightening bolts and securing loose parts to prevent accidents during use.
Recording maintenance activities and tracking services needed in the near future.

tasks.task: Treating animal injuries.
subtasks: Identifying the type and severity of the injury, whether it's external (e.g., cuts, sprains) or internal (e.g., broken bones, gasping).
Administering first aid, such as cleaning wounds, applying bandages, or giving pain relief.
Administering antibiotics or other medications as prescribed by a veterinarian.
Ensuring proper rest and restricted movement to aid recovery.
Following up on the animal’s condition and readjusting treatment as necessary.

tasks.task: Planting trees and shrubs for windbreaks.
subtasks: Selecting the appropriate species of trees or shrubs suitable for the region and intended purpose (e.g., erosion control, carbon capture).
Digging holes as deep as the root ball and twice as wide, adding compost or humus to the backfill.
Planting the trees or shrubs by the hole and backfilling with soil, tamping down to eliminate air pockets.
Watering thoroughly after planting and mulching around the base to retain moisture.
Installing stakes or cages to provide structural support until roots take hold.

tasks.task: Checking the drainage of a hayfield to prevent compaction.
subtasks: Observing the field for standing water after rain to identify areas needing improvement.
Hiring a grading or drainage contractor to install subsurface drain tiles or surface ditches.
Monitoring the drainage system's performance over time and making adjustments as needed.
Compacting the soil in low-lying areas to improve aeration and root growth.

tasks.task: Implementing integrated pest management (IPM) practices.
subtasks: Monitoring crops regularly for signs of pests or disease.
Adopting non-chemical controls, such as crop rotation, intercropping, or introducing predators.
Using chemical pesticides only as a last resort and following strict guidelines.
Monitoring the effectiveness of the control measures and readjusting practices if necessary.
Keeping records of pest incidences and treatments for future reference and planning.

tasks.task: Adding bedding material to dairy cow stalls.
subtasks: Selecting an appropriate bedding material, such as straw, shavings, or wood chips.
Depending on the manure management system, either spreading the manure in fields (front-loading machine) or disposing of it elsewhere.
Adding the bedding around each stall, ensuring even distribution and that the cows have enough space to lie down comfortably.
Cleaning the existing bedding and disposing of any contaminated materials.
Check that the bedding is dry enough to absorb moisture, preventing the spread of disease.

tasks.task: Harvesting garlic during the right window.
subtasks: Deciding the optimal time to harvest garlic (usually when the lower third of the stalk has dried and fallen over).
Using a fork or a flat shovel to dig up the garlic gently to avoid breaks.
Cleaning the garlic by knocking off excess soil and leaving it to dry in a cool, well-ventilated area for several days.
Cutting the tops of the bulbs but leaving 1-2 inches of stem to facilitate upright drying on racks or mesh.

tasks.task: Winterizing a milking parlour.
subtasks: Ensuring that all pipes, valves, and machinery in the parlour are properly insulated or drained to prevent freezing.
Checking that all doors and windows are sealed to keep drafts out and the parlor warm (around 65-70 degrees Fahrenheit).
Inspecting the sprinkler systems or fans for proper operation and adjusting heater settings as needed.
Stocking up on feed, bedding materials, and other essentials to prepare for the winter months.
Conducting a final safety check to ensure emergency exits are clear and equipment is operational.

tasks.task: Conducting a frost check at the vineyard.
subtasks: Using a temperature logger or handheld thermometer to monitor air temperatures around the vines.
Observing the canopy for any signs of frost damage, such as browning or wilting of leaves.
Deciding if a protective measure (e.g., wind machine activation, sprinkler irrigation, uses water to release heat when vaporized) is necessary.
Implementing the chosen frost protection strategy and monitoring its effectiveness throughout the night.
After the threat passes, assessing any damage and planning recovery actions.

tasks.task: Transferring produce from a hydroponic system to market.
subtasks: Checking the nutrient solution levels and pH in the hydroponic tanks.
Removing plants from the system, gently rinsing off the root structure and any growth media.
Sorting the produce into categories based on size, maturity, and freshness.
Packing the plants into coolers or containers with fresh air circulation to maintain quality.
Coordinating delivery to the market or distribution center, ensuring time constraints are considered.

tasks.task: Managing livestock weight through feed adjustments.
subtasks: Regularly weighing a sample of the herd to monitor overall average weights.
Analyzing weight trends and adjusting feed rations as needed (increasing for weight gain or decreasing for weight maintenance or loss).
Adjusting the formulation of the feed (e.g., adding more calories, protein, or fiber) to meet the targeted weight gain.
Monitoring the animals’ appetite, activity levels, and body condition score monthly.
Consulting with a nutritionist if variances from the target weight develop.

tasks.task: Breeding beef cows to increase herd size.
subtasks: Ensuring the presence of a suitable bull or breeding facility (artificial insemination).
Timing the introduction of the bull (or the first service by a studied bull) to coincide with the cows’ estrus cycles.
Regularly checking for signs of pregnancy, such as a swollen udder or behavioral changes.
Tracking the pregnancy check results and adjusting the calving schedule as needed.
Preparing pens or pastures for the new arrivals.

tasks.task: Checking for signs of flooding and erosion along creeks on the property.
subtasks: Walking along the creek banks and identifying any areas with saturated soil, uprooted plants, or washed-out sections.
Evaluating the creek’s current flow rate and potential for flash flooding during heavy rainfall.
Consulting with a natural resource manager or engineer to determine necessary restoration measures.
Implementing erosion control methods, such as planting vegetation, installing ripraps, or constructing check dams.
Regularly monitoring the creek’s condition and adjusting measures as needed.

tasks.task: Assisting in the birth of twin calves.
subtasks: Recognizing that the cow is in labor by increased panting, vocalizing, and frequent lying down.
Preparing the delivery area by cleaning and gathering essential tools (clean towels, needle and thread, etc.).
Observing the first calf's progress, intervening if the second calf is presenting before the first is fully born.
Separating the calves once born, providing colostrum (if necessary) and monitoring their health.
Returning the mother to her pen and checking on her periodically for signs of well-being.

tasks.task: Installing a Compass steering system on a tractor.
subtasks: Reviewing the tractor’s compatibility with the Compass system and obtaining necessary hardware.
Attaching the Compass navigation module to the tractor’s dashboard or supplied bracket.
Programming the Compass with field maps, speed limits, and desired patterns for the current task (such as planting or spraying).
Connecting the system to the tractor’s hydraulic system for precise operation.
Using the GPS to direct the tractor through the field, manually operating adjusts as needed.

tasks.task: Installing soil moisture sensors.
subtasks: Selecting thecorrect depth and model of sensor based on the soil type and crop water needs.
Marking the spots where sensors will be installed, typically along the center of rows or in the furrow.
Using a soil corer or auger to dig a hole, inserting the sensor, and backfilling with soil.
Connecting the sensors to a data logger or monitoring system which can record and analyze water use.
Setting up alarms or notifications for when moisture levels drop below a specified threshold, so irrigation can be scheduled accordingly.

tasks.task: Driving a combine harvester with grain cart on a grain harvest.
subtasks: Attaching the grain cart to the combine and connecting the unloading chute.
Ensuring proper communication between the operator and the unloader of the cart for efficient operation.
Adjusting the combine’s shaker screens, fan speeds, and elevation as needed to match the grain moisture and type.
Analyzing the grain’s moisture content to determine when it is sufficiently dry for storage.
Coordinating with the grain train to connect the auger into the storage bin system when available.

tasks.task: Regrading a field after heavy rains.
subtasks: Conducting a visual assessment of the field to identify low-lying areas and rills caused by runoff.
Using a excavator or tractor equipped with blades to reroute the water flow and flatten the ground.
Tilling any regraded areas to incorporate previous residue or incorporate lime/sand as needed.
Conducting a follow-up assessment after rain events to check if the regrading was effective or further adjustments are needed.

tasks.task: Pruning grape vines during dormant season.
subtasks: Determining which canes to retain based on their productivity in previous years.
Removing excessive growth, dead or diseased wood, and any branches that cross or rub against each other.
Cutting canes back to the desired amount (typically 6-10 buds per cane) to encourage fruiting laterals.
Trellising or cordon training the grape vines to the post or wire support system.
Applying a dormant oil or fungicide if needed to prevent pests or disease over winter.

tasks.task: Maintaining a hydroponic system.
subtasks: Regularly checking the water levels and refilling if necessary.
Monitoring the nutrient solution’s pH and electrical conductivity, adjusting as needed.
Inspecting the plant roots for signs of nutrient deficiencies, infections, or physical damage.
Cleaning the system’s filters and reservoirs every few weeks to prevent bacterial growth or clogging.
Routine aeration checks to ensure sufficient oxygen is reaching the roots.

tasks.task: Assisting a veterinarian in a calf birth.
subtasks: Noticing the signs that a mother cow is about to give birth (vaginal discharge, udder development).
Calling the veterinarian and preparing the birthing area.
Assisting the veterinarian in positioning the calf, applying lubricant if necessary.
Helping to clear the calf’s airway by gently pulling on the lower jaw and striking the chest if necessary.
Monitoring the cow and the newborn’s health, noting any signs of retained placenta, and administering antibiotics if needed.

tasks.task: Monitoring solar panel output and adjusting tilt angles.
subtasks: Using a meter or software to check the solar panel’s DC and AC outputs.
Checking for shading from trees or other structures that could block sunlight on the panels.
Collecting data over time to optimize tilt angles for maximum energy production different seasons, considering tilt changes based on location.
Performing a thorough check of hardware and connections annually for safety.

tasks.task: Applying plastic wrap to harvested carrots for market display.
subtasks: Sorting carrots by size and appearance.
Washing the carrots in cool water, removing any dirt or roots.
Cutting the tops off the carrots and smoothing the cuts, making them uniform for marketing.
Wrapping individual carrots or bundling them in plastic bags labeled with their variety and harvest date.
Storing the packaged carrots in a cool place (40-50 degrees Fahrenheit) until they are sold at the market.

tasks.task: Installing a new watering system for poultry.
subtasks: Purchasing and selecting appropriate equipment (ground waterers, nipple drinkers, etc.).
Constructing a PVC tubing or metal framework to support the waterers’ height.
Connecting the water supply to the system, ensuring the pressure is sufficient.
Integrating the water system with the existing feed system if constantly checking both.

tasks.task: Overwintering chickens in a coop.
subtasks: Ensuring the coop has adequate insulation (adding straw bales behind walls or under the floor).
Ventilating the coop to prevent excess moisture buildup, using trickle vents or automatic draft excluders.
Heating the coop with an oil lamp, heat tape on waterers, or heat lamps as needed. Monitoring temperatures to avoid over-heating or frostbite.
Supplementing feed with higher energy-dense foods to keep the chickens warm in cold weather.
Checking for drafts and sealing gaps in the coop’s structure to retain heat.

tasks.task: Preparing a grain drydown fan for operation.
subtasks: Checking the fan’s blades for damage or buildup, cleaning them if necessary.
Ensuring the electrical connections are safe, conducting a functional test run.
Supplying adequate airflow by opening baffles or louvers in the grain bin’s vents.
Measuring the temperature fluctuations inside the bin over the night to gauge effectiveness.
Coordinating with operations to use the fan when necessary, usually during early mornings or late evenings when temperatures are lower.

tasks.task: Conducting a land survey for potential farm expansion.
subtasks: Gathering maps, aerial images, and existing property boundary records.
Using GPS technology or a manual transit to map the land’s contours and features.
Noting the location of existing structures, roads, and water features.
Evaluating the topography for infrastructure feasibility (irrigation, drainage, bridges).
Presenting findings and proposed layouts to the farm management team for approval.

tasks.task: Inspecting a pivoted sprinkler system for leaks.
subtasks: Walking through the irrigation area to visually inspect the sprinkler heads for broken or misaligned components.
Activating the pivot system and observing for any variations in spray patterns or water volume.
Checking control valves for leaks or clogs, locating them if necessary.
Isolating sections of the system for repair if a leak is detected and determining its cause.
Replacing any faulty components, such as solenoids, filters, or spray nozzles.

tasks.task: Removing damaging weeds from a row crop field.
subtasks: Selecting the appropriate herbicide or tillage method based on the type and density of weeds.
Applying the chemical treatment at the recommended rate or using multiple passes with a cultivator.
Wearing protective clothing and following safety guidelines when using herbicides.
Observing the effects of the treatment after a few days and respraying if necessary.
Checking for missed areas or outliers that need supplemental control measures.

tasks.task: Applying mulch to strawberry beds to suppress weeds and provide insulation.
subtasks: Purchasing or gathering the appropriate type of mulch (e.g., wood chips, straw, plastic sheeting).
Laying down the mulch between plants, piling it up 2-4 inches high to smother weeds.
Ensuring air and water can still reach the plants through the mulch. For example, using woven landscape fabric or slits cut into the mulch.
Watering the mulch in to help it settle and bond with the soil.

tasks.task: Transporting manure from a barn to a field.
subtasks: Loading the manure into a wagon or trailer using a skid steer or tractor with a loader.
Checking the load's stability to prevent spills during transport.
Ventilating the vehicle’s bed if covered to prevent odors and promote air circulation.
Choosing a logical route to minimize traffic on rough terrain and block driveways.
Unloading the manure at the desired field location, spreading it evenly with a loader or spreader.

tasks.task: Extending a hay bale feeder to reduce forage waste.
subtasks: Measuring the current length of the bale feeder and determining the desired extension.
Attaching or replacing the retaining rods or chains to adjust the distance between the hoppers.
Ensuring the extended feeder’s smooth operation and its ability to retain the bales without leaking.
Tying off the ends of the extended part with rope or chains to keep them in place.
Testing the extended feeder with a portion of hay to confirm it works effectively.

tasks.task: Injecting a water solution into soil for enhanced fertilization.
subtasks: Choosing a water-soluble fertilizer that addresses the current soil deficiencies.
Preparing the solution according to the manufacturer’s instructions or using a professional formula.
Ensuring the distribution is even and that nozzles are clean to prevent clogging.
Tracking soil readings over time and adjusting the injection rate based on progress.

tasks.task: Treating a sick horse for a respiratory infection.
subtasks: Isolating the horse from the herd to prevent spread of the infection.
Collecting a sample for lab analysis or consulting a veterinarian if needed.
Administering antibiotics (prescribed by a veterinarian) and anti-inflammatory drugs.
Ensuring the horse has a quiet, clean stall and plenty of fresh air.
Monitoring vital signs and breathing every few hours until recovery.

tasks.task: Installing a fence to contain wildlife in a garden.
subtasks: Assessing the garden’s perimeter to identify weak points where animals can enter.
Choosing the type of fencing (electric, mesh, wire) based on the threat and cost.
Building or purchasing the fencing posts and materials, ensuring they are tall enough to deter burrowing animals.
Tying the wire or attaching mesh panels between the posts, securing them tightly around the garden edges.

tasks.task: Checking a portable chlorinator system for a livestock water source.
subtasks: Daily check of the chlorinator’s chemical levels, refilling or replacing as needed.
Sample testing the water for pH and residual chlorine to ensure proper hygiene.
Checking the pump and entire system for any leaks or corrosion.
Servicing the chlorinator’s timer or settings periodically to adjust for seasonal variations.
Cleaning any mineral buildup in the delivery lines and replacing filters when necessary.

tasks.task: Conducting a soil test to determine pH and nutrient levels.
subtasks: Collecting soil samples from various parts of the field using a soil probe or corer.
Sending the samples to a laboratory for analysis, interpreting the results for pH, Nitrogen, Phosphorus, Potassium, etc.
Applying corrective actions such as lime, fertilizer, or other amendments based on the test results.
Following up with another test in a year to evaluate the effectiveness of the amendments applied.
Keeping records of soil tests and amendments over time to track progress and adjust future practices.

tasks.task: Treating a case of mastitis in dairy cows.
subtasks: Identifying the presence of mastitis through signs like abnormal milk, fever, or swelling.
Milk the gland(s) and discard the milk during treatment.
Use a collection bag or teat cup to apply intramammary antibiotics via the teat canal.
Follow-up examination after seven days, milking the cow before checking the udder.
Discard milk for 3-5 days past the withdrawal period and test subsequent milk to confirm clearance.

tasks.task: Checking actuators on a wind turbine for proper functioning.
subtasks: Accessing the turbine’s nacelle or actuator controls from the ground or platform.
Inspecting the wiring and connections for any signs of damage or corrosion.
Adjusting the pitch mechanism manually if possible or verifying potentially faulty electronics.
Testing the system response with a simulated gust or by means of a test button.
Recording the readings and troubleshooting any inconsistencies with manufacturer specifications.

tasks.task: Preparing a nursery greenhouse for a new planting season.
subtasks: Cleaning the greenhouse thoroughly, removing debris and old growing media.
Checking the glass or panels for any damage or replacement needs.
Attaching crop supports (hoops, trellises) as needed for the upcoming crop types.
Checking irrigation lines for leaks and ensuring a reliable water source.
Applying a fresh layer of mulch or cover crop to the planting beds if not permanent structures.

tasks.task: Starting a planting season with early-planted crops.
subtasks: Setting up row covers or cold frames to protect sensitive seedlings from frost.
Watering and monitoring the seeds or transplants closely for success.
Thinning plants as they emerge, spacing them apart to give each sufficient room to grow.
Applying supplemental nutrients via organic or inorganic fertilizers when needed.
Marking crop rows and dates of planting for easy reference.

tasks.task: Servicing a thermal heating system in a dairy barn.
subtasks: Checking burners, heat exchangers, and safety devices for proper functioning.
Cleaning or replacing filters in the heating system to improve efficiency and air quality.
Testing thermostats and timing devices to ensure they are set to the correct temperature thresholds.
Checking for adequate oxygen levels in the barn to prevent buildup of carbon monoxide from the heating system.
Ensuring emergency shutoff mechanisms are operational in case of system failure.

tasks.task: Treating wool sheep for flystrike.
subtasks: Examining each sheep for signs of fly strike (butterfly-like maggots around wounds or moist areas).
Applying a泻药 to disperse any maggots present and cleaning the affected area.
Dipping the sheep with a flystrike prevention product (e.g., ivermectin), following the manufacturer’s instructions.
Isolating affected sheep to prevent re-infestation and monitoring their health regularly.

tasks.task: Planting nut trees for long-term orchard development.
subtasks: Purchasing or acquiring nut trees (e.g., hazelnut, walnut) that are adapted to the local climate.
Digging holes at the correct spacing (usually 20 x 20 feet) to provide room for root growth.
Staking the trees to provide support and protect them from wind damage.
Pruning any damaged branches and applying mulch around the base to retain moisture and prevent weeds.

tasks.task: Undertaking organic mulch application to garden beds.
subtasks: Chopping up any large organic materials (e.g., fallen leaves, grass clippings) if necessary.
Applying a 2-3 inch layer of mulch around annual and perennial plants, keeping it a few inches away from stems.
Raking or pushing the mulch into place, ensuring even coverage across the garden beds.
Dealing with drainage issues by not piling mulch too thickly around plant’s root zones.
Monitoring the mulch layer in the growing season and replenishing as needed to maintain depth.

tasks.task: Building a new livestock shelter to prevent weather-related stress.
subtasks: Choosing the appropriate shelter type (open-front, three-sided, fully enclosed) based on animal species and climate.
Locating the shelter’s position away from prevailing winds and easy access for animals.
Measuring materials needed for the structure (steel poles, roofing material, siding) and budgeting.
Framing the shelter with a post and beam system, securing the roof and walls with weatherproof materials.
Adding ventilation openings high in the sides for heat escape in summer and blocking in winter.

tasks.task: Installing windbreaks around a farm plot.
subtasks: Planning the windbreak layout to intercept winds most commonly felt on the property.
Selecting suitable trees and shrubs for the region’s climatic conditions (e.g., evergreens for year-round coverage).

tasks.task: Performing a routine inspection of an alpaca’s hooves.
subtasks: Scheduling appointments during times when alpacas are calmer and less stressed (mornings or after feedings).
Gathering necessary tools: hoof shears, file, disinfectant.
Gently holding the alpaca to steady it, preferably in a crush stall.
Examining each foot for signs of overgrowth, cracks, or injuries.
Trimming overgrown hooves while keeping the white line intact, applying hoof dressing.

tasks.task: Recording field data with an app on a smartphone while drilling.
subtasks: Ensuring the phone is charged and has a data connection or offline access for critical tasks.
Launching the field management application and selecting the current job or field.
Entering details such as the crop, seed variety, planting depth, and row spacing.
Pinpointing the exact location within the field using GPS coordinates for accurate mapping.
Taking notes on any observations or issues encountered during planting.

tasks.task: Applying compost to perennial beds.
subtasks: Weeding the beds to prepare for feeding, ensuring that compost is applied on clean ground.
Testing the acidity of the compost using a pH kit to ensure it isn’t too alkaline or acidic.
Spreading the compost uniformly over the soil surface using a garden fork or rototiller.
Incorporating the compost into the top 6-8 inches of soil using a spade or tiller.

tasks.task: Adjusting PTO speeds on farm equipment.
subtasks: Locating the PTO (Power Take-Off) and raising it to the appropriate angle.
Engaging the PTO switch and checking for proper rotation speed.

tasks.task: Tamping down soil in a newly tilled field.
subtasks: Walking behind a cultivator or driving a tractor with a ripper/till attachment.
Alternating directions for even distribution of the tillage.
Breaking up clumps of soil with a rake or excess clumping that may have formed during tilling.
Moving es to another likely task.

tasks.task: Cleaning the inside surfaces of greenhouses from accumulated mold or algae.
subtasks: Using a mild soap solution and a sponge or soft brush to scrub the affected areas.
Rinsing thoroughly to remove all soap and algae particles.
Focusing on areas where mold or algae growth is thickest, such as along the frame or at water condensation points.
Maintaining good ventilation to reduce future growth by removing excess moisture.
Schedule periodic cleanings to prevent buildup and monitor the effectiveness of cleaning methods.

tasks.task: Adjusting the auger speed on a grain combine.
subtasks: Stopping the combine and disconnecting the power to the auger.
Using a stopwatch or timer to check the amount of grain unloaded per minute.
Making adjustments to the auger s

tasks.task: Conducting a barn safety inspection.
subtasks: Checking for hazards such as electrical wires near feeders, sharp objects on walkways, or slippery surfaces.
Ensuring fire extinguishers are accessible and functional, with regular inspections.
Verifying maintenance schedules for equipment (e.g., fences, water systems) are up-to-date.
Inspecting odors from manure and taking steps to improve ventilation or reduce buildup.
Training staff on emergency procedures, such as fire drills or evacuation routes.

tasks.task: Installing a new barn roof.
subtasks: Ascertaining the necessary materials based on the roof’s desired lifespan and leak resistance (shingles, metal sheets).
Measuring the roof’s dimensions to determine the quantity of tarice needed.
Removing the existing roof (if applicable), disposing of any debris or damaged shingles.
Attaching new sheathing or existing structure for reinforcement, if required.
Applying the roofing material, starting from the bottom edge and moving upward, overlapping seams according to manufacturer’s instructions.

tasks.task: Winterizing a solar-powered lighting system.
subtasks: Checking the battery status and charging system's efficiency.
Changing out any belts or gaskets that may have been damaged during the season.
Inspecting the solar panel's position for optimal sun exposure, adjusting if necessary.
Ensuring adequate drainage of rainwater from the solar modules to prevent water pooling.
Wrapping the system in insulation or thick plastic to keep components warm in freezing temperatures.

tasks.task: Installing a slotted drain pipe along the perimeter of a field to control water flow.
subtasks: Marking the path of the pipe according to the field’s irregularities and planned drainage direction.

tasks.task: Applying manure compost to a garden plot.
subtasks: Mixing the compost with garden soil to a depth of 6-8 inches using a spade or tiller.

tasks.task: Constructing a feed storage facility for pods (potato crops).
MAINTASK 马king a reed韵 楣子
Driving a combine harvester during harvest time.
subtasks: Securing the safety belts and checking for proper equipment connection to the combine.
Adjusting the combine’s auger speed and fan settings in real-time based on crop conditions.
Maintaining a steady pace while harvesting, ensuring crops are cut at the right height.
Monitoring the grain bin's capacity and coordinating with grain carts or trucks for timely unloading.

tasks.task: Checking the oil level in a combine's engine.
perhaps MAINTASK: Loading hay baler onto a trailer, with relevant subtasks. Otherwise, due to limited content, I'll try providing three possible tasks. Alternatively, maybe a different orientation.
Loading hay into a storage container.
subtasks: Positioning the hay carrier alongside the hay pile.
Using a pitchfork to transfer hay from the pile into the carrier.
Ensuring even distribution of hay across the carrier.
Securing the load to prevent shifting.

tasks.task: Operating a combine harvester.
subtasks: Adjusting the harvester’s settings for the current crop.
Navigating the harvester through the field.
Monitoring grain flow and making adjustments.
Verifying the harvester’s efficiency.

tasks.task: Planting crops using a tractor and planter.
subtasks: Attaching the planters to the tractor.
Running the tractor through seed beds.
Checking the plant spacing and depth.
Verifying grain moisture levels.

tasks.task: Feeding livestock.
subtasks: Mixing feed for maximum nutrition.
Distributing feed evenly in the enclosure.
Cleaning the enclosure between feedings.
Monitoring the animals' feeding habits.

tasks.task: Repairing farm machinery.
subtasks: Identifying the problem with the equipment.
Removing faulty components.
Reassembling the machinery and testing it.

tasks.task: Milking cows.
subtasks: Attaching the milking unit to the cow.
Monitoring milk quality and machine function.
Hand washing the udders.
Disconnecting the unit after milking.

tasks.task: Constructing a fence.
subtasks: Measuring the area for fence posts.
Driving fence posts into the ground.
Stretching wire between posts.
Securing the wire tensioners.
Inspecting animals for signs of illness.
Documenting any issues observed.
Adjusting feeding rations for sick animals.

tasks.task: Applying fertilizer.
subtasks: Broadcasting the fertilizer on the field.
Overlapping passes to cover all areas.
Cleaning the spreader after use.

tasks.task: Pruning trees.
subtasks: 选取需要修剪的树枝。

tasks.task: Planting trees.
subtasks: Digging planting holes.
Planting the trees and backfilling soil.
Watering the newly planted trees.
